item.title: Egyptian Forces Storm Pro-Morsi Sit-Ins
item.description: The Egyptian authorities on Wednesday used armored vehicles and fired tear gas to clear two camps in Cairo occupied by supporters of the ousted president, Mohamed Morsi.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK and ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: A tent was set ablaze by the security forces as they moved to clear out the protesters Wednesday.

item.title: Disappearance of Activist Priest in Syria Stirs Fears He Is Dead
item.description: The Rev. Paolo Dallâ€™Oglio, who has spent decades promoting religious dialogue in Syria and championed the uprising, has been missing and unconfirmed reports that he has been killed have become common.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD

item.title: Koreas Agree to Reopen Industrial Park in North
item.description: In a sign that the two sides are heading toward a diplomatic thaw, they agreed to revive the last remaining symbol of their economic cooperation.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: India Ink: Faces of Pakistan
item.description: Multiple facets of Pakistan as a nuclear armed country as it celebrates its 67th year of independence.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Explosion Partly Sinks Indian Naval Submarine
item.description: The blast ripped through the Russian-made vessel, which was docked in Mumbai, and left an unknown toll, with at least 18 navy personnel reported trapped.
item.dc:creator: By GARDINER HARRIS
item.media:description: The naval yard in Mumbai where an explosion and fire on the diesel-powered submarine INS Sindhurakshak partially sunk the vessel on Wednesday, trapping 18 sailors on board.

item.title: Israel Strikes 2 Gaza Sites Hours Before Start of Talks
item.description: The airstrikes Wednesday, hours before Israeli-Palestinian negotiations were to begin, were in response to rocket fire, the Israeli military said.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER and RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Egyptian Troops Move Against Pro-Morsi Sit-Ins
item.description: Egyptian security forces, backed by armored cars and bulldozers, moved on Wednesday to clear two sit-in camps by supporters of the ousted president, Mohammed Morsi, showering protesters with tear gas as gunfire rang out at both sites.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Egyptian Security Forces Move to Clear Out Pro-Morsi Sit-Ins
item.description: Egyptian security forces have started clearing out Cairo protesters who have been demanding the reinstatement of the deposed president, Mohamed Morsi.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing | Africa: Libya: Berbers Protest in Assembly
item.description: Members of the ethnic Berber minority on Tuesday forced their way into the Parliament building in Tripoli, demanding that Berber be made an official language.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Explosion Partly Sinks Indian Naval Submarine
item.description: The blast ripped through the Russian-made vessel, which was docked in Mumbai on Wednesday, and left an unknown toll, with at least 18 personnel reported trapped.
item.dc:creator: By GARDINER HARRIS

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: China: Foreign Tourism Falls, and Smog May Be One Reason
item.description: Among the factors cited for the significant drop in the number of tourists this year to China were smog, the sluggish global economy, a stronger Chinese currency and the bird flu.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Hackers Attack Web Site of Tibetan Government in Exile
item.description: Hackers rigged the Web site of the Central Tibetan Administration to infect the computers of Chinese-speaking visitors with rogue software, a researcher said Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: President Rules Out Reversal of Berlusconiâ€™s Fraud Conviction
item.description: President Giorgio Napolitano on Tuesday said he would not reverse the tax fraud conviction of Silvio Berlusconi and warned his party against trying to bring down the government over the issue.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing | The Americas: Canada: Railroad Company to Be Shut Down
item.description: Canada plans to shut the rail operator whose tanker train blew up in a Quebec town last month, killing 47 people, because the company does not have enough insurance to pay for cleanup costs.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Merkel Enters Last Leg of Re-election Bid With a Push to Draw In Youths
item.description: With a month to go in her re-election campaign, Chancellor Angela Merkel faces disdain from Germanyâ€™s intelligentsia and questions about American surveillance efforts.
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE
item.media:description: Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany lectured a class Tuesday on the 52nd anniversary of the building of the Berlin Wall.

item.title: San CristÃ³bal de Las Casas Journal: In Mexico, a Healer Who Asks for Nothing in Return
item.description: Sergio Castro, 72, is neither doctor nor priest, but he fills a gap in Mexicoâ€™s ragged safety net in health care, accepting no money from his patients, who are mostly Mayans.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETH MALKIN
item.media:credit: Janet Jarman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sergio Castro made his way up a steep hill to one of his patientâ€™s homes. He visits people who are too ill to make it to his clinic.

item.title: Israel Releases 26 Palestinian Prisoners, to Cheers and Anguish
item.description: The move was part of a deal brokered by the United States allowing the resumption of peace talks on Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:credit: Mahmud Hams/Agence France-Presse â€” Getty Images
item.media:description: A bus with freed Palestinians was thronged near the Erez crossing between Israel and the Gaza Strip early Wednesday morning.

item.title: Germany Fights Population Drop
item.description: As German towns work to hide the emptiness, demographers say a similar fate awaits other European countries, with frightening implications for the economy.
item.dc:creator: By SUZANNE DALEY and NICHOLAS KULISH
item.media:credit: Djamila Grossman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Germany is looking for ways to encourage working mothers. This 24-hour kindergarten, for example, caters to parents who work overnight.

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: Obama, Snowden and Putin
item.description: The Russian president is doing more harm at home than anywhere else.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN

item.title: Questions Follow Acid Attack on British Women in Zanzibar
item.description: Two young volunteers from London who had been briefed on how to conduct themselves during Ramadan were doused with acid by two men on a moped.
item.dc:creator: By KATRIN BENNHOLD
item.media:description: Katie Gee and Kirstie Trup, both 18 and from London, at the airport in Zanzibar on Thursday. Two men on a moped doused them with acid the day before.

item.title: Oil Reforms by Mexico May Upend Markets
item.description: The suggested policy changes could reinvigorate the countryâ€™s oil industry and ease American dependence on OPEC, experts say.
item.dc:creator: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS
item.media:description: A state-owned oil platform in the Gulf of Mexico. A reform to Mexican energy laws could revitalize the national oil industry.

item.title: Appointment of 19 Generals as Provincial Governors Raises Fears in Egypt
item.description: The move was a return to a tactic used by President Hosni Mubarak, in which governorships are dangled to cultivate top officersâ€™ loyalty while extending the police stateâ€™s grip.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK and MAYY EL SHEIKH
item.media:description: An Egyptian injured in clashes over the ousted president, Mohamed Morsi, was taken for treatment Tuesday in Cairo.

item.title: In Brazil, Kerry Is Told Spying Sows â€˜Distrustâ€™
item.description: Brazilâ€™s foreign minister dismissed Secretary of State John Kerryâ€™s explanation of the data collection by the National Security Agency and said it â€œcast a shadow of distrustâ€ over bilateral relations.
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO

item.title: Safety Concerns Delay U.N. Chemical Arms Inquiry in Syria
item.description: The United Nations said an agreement still required finalization to ensure the safety of the investigators.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: The Lede: Norwegian Leaderâ€™s Not-So-Candid Camera
item.description: What at first appeared to be a daring political stunt â€” having Norwayâ€™s prime minister drive a cab to listen in on the national conversation â€” turns out to have been at least partly staged.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY
